column1: The Dunwich horror itself came between Lammas and the equinox in 1928
column2: and Dr. Armitage was among those who witnessed its monstrous prologue. He had heard
column4: of Whateley's grotesque trip to Cambridge
column5: and of his frantic efforts to borrow or copy from the Necronomicon at the Widener Library. Those efforts had been in vain
column6: since Armitage had issued warnings of the keenest intensity to all librarians having charge of the dreaded volume. Wilbur had been shockingly nervous at Cambridge; anxious for the book
column7: yet almost equally anxious to get home again
column8: as if he feared the results of being away long.Early in August the half-expected outcome developed
column9: and in the small hours of the third Dr. Armitage was awakened suddenly by the wild
column10: fierce cries of the savage watchdog on the college campus. Deep and terrible
column12: half-mad growls and barks continued; always in mounting volume
column13: but with hideously significant pauses. Then there rang out a scream from a wholly different throat—such a scream as roused half the sleepers of Arkham and haunted their dreams ever afterward—such a scream as could come from not being born of earth
